abstract.p: Kyron Huigens letter rebuts Repr Asa Hutchinson's opinion that use of DNA testing threatens to deprive juries of central role in criminal trials

block.p: Contrary to Asa Hutchinson's fear (Op-Ed, June 22), the use of DNA testing in no way threatens to deprive the jury of its central role in criminal trials.

Often, no blood or tissue can be found at a crime scene, and DNA evidence is simply unavailable. Furthermore, eyewitness testimony and DNA are both relevant only to the issue of identity. Identity is not always, or even usually, the central issue in a criminal trial.
Contrary to Asa Hutchinson's fear (Op-Ed, June 22), the use of DNA testing in no way threatens to deprive the jury of its central role in criminal trials.

Often, no blood or tissue can be found at a crime scene, and DNA evidence is simply unavailable. Furthermore, eyewitness testimony and DNA are both relevant only to the issue of identity. Identity is not always, or even usually, the central issue in a criminal trial.

More often, the identity of the perpetrator is known, but the issue is whether he was acting in self-defense, was insane or intended to inflict harm. The jury is, and will remain, responsible for deciding these issues.
The writer is an associate professor, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law.
